abstract.p: Difficulties in the administering of stabilization programs may arise due to lags. Due to the existence of lags, stabilization policies may be destabilizing in their effect, regardless of the fact that the new equilibrium position for the economy—determined by a comparative statics analaysis—is in proper position relative to that the policy makers were seeking to change. By the use of a mix of policies it is possible to minimize the destabilizing effect of stabilization programs. The model used makes certain assumptions relative to lags in the economy, but so long as the various weapons in the policy maker's arsenal have different effects on the frequency and amplitude of cycles in the economy their resultant may well be of minor importance. It is possible, of course, that the simultaneous application of certain policies may result in the maximization of instability.
